TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and is presently detained at ORG prison .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG filed a bill of indictment against the applicant charging him with CARDINAL counts of rape under aggravated circumstances , i.e. having caused serious injuries . ORG submitted that on DATE the applicant had raped ORG , had beaten and strangled her , had forced her to swallow drugs and had threatened her with death . On DATE he had raped ORG , had beaten and strangled her , had forced her to swallow drugs , had burned her skin with cigarettes and had cut her vagina with a knife causing a deep laceration as well as opening the abdominal cavity .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Geschworenengericht ) of ORG ( PERSON ) convicted the applicant of both offences of aggravated rape and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . In assessing the penalty , the court considered as mitigating circumstances the applicant ’s partial confession regarding the rape of ORG and , to some extent , that he had acted under the influence of alcohol and drugs . As aggravating circumstances , the court considered the applicant ’s criminal record , the fact that he had committed CARDINAL rapes and the extreme brutality which the applicant had shown when committing the offences .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a plea of nullity ( GPE ) and an appeal against sentence ( GPE ) . In his plea of nullity the applicant complained , inter alia , that ORG had failed to hear the requested witnesses from GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Oberster Gerichtshof ) confirmed ORG judgment as regards the rape of ORG and quashed the judgment as regards the other charge of rape and the sentence . It found that there had been sufficient information to identify the witnesses from GPE and that ORG should have attempted to take this evidence . It remitted the case to that court .

CARDINAL . On DATE the new trial commenced before ORG sitting with another jury and on DATE ORG convicted the applicant of raping PERSON and sentenced him to DATE imprisonment . When fixing the sentence the court considered as mitigating circumstances the applicant ’s confession regarding some of the facts concerning the charge of having raped ORG and , to a certain extent , his intoxication . As aggravating circumstances it considered the applicant ’s criminal record , that he had committed CARDINAL rapes and his extreme brutality when committing the offences .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a plea of nullity and an appeal against sentence . In his appeal against sentence the applicant submitted that ORG had failed to give sufficient weight to the mitigating circumstances , namely his neglected education , his difficult childhood and his intoxication . The applicant did not request to attend the hearings before ORG or ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , sitting in private , rejected as inadmissible the applicant ’s plea of nullity .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG fixed the hearing date for the applicant ’s appeal against the sentence for DATE . The applicant received a notification which stated that he , being detained , could only appear through his counsel and would not be brought to the court as the conditions of LAW [ LAW § CARDINAL ] of LAW ( GPE ) were not fulfilled .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , after having held a hearing in the absence of the applicant but in the presence of his defence counsel , dismissed the appeal against the sentence . As regards the weighing of mitigating and aggravating circumstances by ORG , ORG found that the applicant ’s partial confession was merely a contribution to the establishment of the truth ( PERSON ) and did not qualify as a mitigating circumstance . Further , there were additional aggravating circumstances such as the particular cruelty which the applicant had used when committing the offences , as well as their concurrent nature ( PERSON strafbarer PERSON ) . As regards the circumstances invoked by the applicant , the

ORG found that they could not be taken into consideration as mitigating circumstances . A neglected education and difficult childhood could not be considered as the applicant was now an adult and it could not explain his excessive use of brutality . Also no weight could be given to his intoxication because he should have known about the effects of alcohol on his person , and the experts had stated that it had no bearing on him committing the offences . Furthermore , the applicant ’s offences were not a consequence of a mental defect but of frustration and increased aggression and he had not shown any consciousness of his guilt . Thus , there was no reason to reduce the sentence .

CARDINAL . A first - instance judgment of an assize court may be challenged by a plea of nullity to ORG on the specific grounds enumerated in section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW The sentence as such may be challenged by way of an appeal against sentence to ORG . It may concern both points of law ( in particular whether mitigating or aggravating circumstances have been correctly taken into account ) and factors relating to the assessment of the sentence . Where the substance of an appeal is examined , a public hearing must normally be held . Unless an appeal against sentence is filed together with a plea of nullity and ORG decides on both remedies , such a hearing is held before ORG .
CARDINAL . As regards the personal appearance of the accused at a public appeal hearing , section CARDINAL § CARDINAL , second sentence , of LAW provides :

“ An accused who is detained shall always be summoned and an accused who is detained shall also be brought before the court if he has made a request to this effect in his appeal or counter - statement or otherwise if his personal presence appears necessary in the interests of justice . ”
